reasoning:
First off, NFLX sits outside my circle of competence. I’m comfortable with businesses I can lay out on a cocktail napkin – soft drinks, insurance, railroads – not complex content licensing and subscriber math. As I always say, “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing.”

Competitive Moat: Netflix shows decent operating margins (~31%), but its moat is far from unassailable. Content costs balloon, competitors (Disney, Amazon, HBO) pile in, and customer switching costs are thin unless you’re bundled with broadband. High performance stability (70%) is encouraging, but inconsistent ROE (0/10 periods above 15%) tells me the economic moat isn’t durable.

Management & Capital Allocation: Reed Hastings has built a global brand, but heavy debt (debt/equity ~3.9) to fund content raises a red flag. No dividends or share buybacks ease this, but I prefer managers who think like owners and don’t lever up the balance sheet so aggressively.

Financial Health & Consistency: Weak ROE (2%), negligible ROIC (~0.4%), and inconsistent earnings (-27.5% over ten periods) clash with my idea of a financial fortress. I’d rather own See’s Candies – predictable cash flow, little debt, steady returns.

Valuation: My DCF pegs a conservative intrinsic value at $403, yet NFLX trades well above that. With a margin of safety at –99%, I’d be overpaying by a wide margin. Remember, “Price is what you pay, value is what you get.”

Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Streaming will mature, competition intensify, and content spending could erode returns. I prefer businesses with pricing power – one where I can raise prices without scaring away customers. That’s not the case here.

Comparison to Portfolio: I’d rather redeploy capital into Coca-Cola’s dependable dividends or Apple’s ecosystem moat. NFLX might entertain millions, but it doesn’t fit my criteria for a forever business purchased at a sensible price.

Bottom line: I’ll pass. There’s no penalty for missing an opportunity, but losing principal by chasing a too-expensive, debt-laden content play? That’s a mistake I’m unwilling to make.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.0%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.9; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -27.5% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 31.9%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (70.0%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
